elements.content: A novel nanoporous metal–organic framework NPC-4 with excellent thermal stability was assembled from 2,3,5,6-tetramethylbenzene-1,4-diisophthalate (TMBDI) and the paddle-wheel secondary building unit (Cu2(COO)4). The porous structure comprises a single type of nanoscale cage (16 Å diameter) interconnected by windows (5.2 × 6.3 Å), which give a high pore volume. CH4 (195–290 K), CO2 (198–303 K), N2 (77 K), and H2 (77 K) adsorption isotherms were studied for pressures up to 20 bar. NPC-4 exhibits excellent methane and carbon dioxide storage capacities on a volume basis with very high adsorbate densities, under ambient conditions. Isobars were investigated to establish the relationship for adsorption capacities over a range of storage temperatures. The isosteric enthalpies of adsorption for both CH4 and CO2 adsorption did not vary significantly with amount adsorbed and were ∼15 and ∼25 kJ mol–1, respectively. The adsorption/desorption kinetics for CH4 and CO2 were investigated and activation energies, enthalpies of activation, and diffusion parameters determined using various kinetic models. The activation energies for adsorption obtained over a range of uptakes from the stretched exponential kinetic model were 5.1–6.3 kJ mol–1 (2–13.5 mmol g–1) for CO2 and 2.7–5.6 kJ mol–1 (2–9 mmol g–1) for CH4. The activation energies for surface barriers and diffusion along pores for both CH4 and CO2 adsorption obtained from a combined barrier resistance diffusion model did not vary markedly with amount adsorbed and were <9 kJ mol–1. Comparison of kinetic and thermodynamic parameters for CH4 and CO2 indicates that a surface barrier is rate determining at high uptakes, while intraparticle diffusion involving diffusion through pores, consisting of narrow windows interconnecting with nanocages, being rate determining at very low uptakes. The faster CH4 intraparticle adsorption kinetics compared with CO2 for NPC-4 was attributed to faster surface diffusion due to the lower isosteric enthalpy of adsorption for CH4.

elements.content: Adsorption on porous materials has many current and potential future applications in gas storage, separation, and purification. Gas separation on porous materials has commercial applications, for example, air separation, carbon dioxide capture, and removal of trace environmentally unfriendly species. Gas storage has potential applications ranging from hydrogen and methane for use in vehicle applications to carbon dioxide capture and sequestration. Gas storage, separation, and purification using porous materials all require relatively fast diffusivity, while storage applications also require high uptake, whereas separation and purification needs high selectivity for specific species.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Adsorption on porous materials has many current and potential future applications in gas storage, separation, and purification. Gas separation on porous materials has commercial applications, for example, air separation, carbon dioxide capture, and removal of trace environmentally unfriendly species. Gas storage has potential applications ranging from hydrogen and methane for use in vehicle applications to carbon dioxide capture and sequestration. Gas storage, separation, and purification using porous materials all require relatively fast diffusivity, while storage applications also require high uptake, whereas separation and purification needs high selectivity for specific species.

elements.content: Methane is a promising energy resource for transport applications in the medium term owing to abundant reserves in both conventional and unconventional resources, such as shale gas. Also, the relatively clean combustion products from methane lead to lower environmental impact. However, the storage of methane for transport applications still remains a challenge because of its low energy density, and the volumetric storage capacity is the important issue. Conventional storage forms of refrigerated liquid or high pressure compressed gas bring many safety concerns and also consume large amounts of energy. Thus, it is essential to develop a safe, economically feasible and effective system for methane storage. Physisorption on porous materials is a potential methane storage method that is under development. The U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) target for methane storage has recently been increased from 180 v­(STP)/v at 35 bar and room temperature to correspond to the density of compressed natural gas (CNG) at 250 bar and 298 K. The targets are 0.5 g­(CH4) per g­(sorbent) and a density of 0.188 g cm–3 for volumetric capacity.

elements.content: Physisorption by porous materials is an attractive method for methane storage due to low heat effects and fast adsorption/desorption kinetics. Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are good candidates for gas storage/separation applications due to the advantage of tunable structure, predictable pore size, and high porosity. Over the past decade, many novel MOF materials have been synthesized based on the methodology of constructing modular molecular building blocks. Various MOF materials have been used for methane storage and many factors have been investigated to maximize the storage capacity, but their importance is unclear. The strategies include (1) constructing MOFs with rationally designed architectures, which exhibit large pore volume, high surface area, and suitable window size; (2) introducing high density of open metal sites; and (3) incorporating functional groups in MOF materials. A recent computational study has screened out the best MOFs for the target of methane storage from thousands of hypothetical MOFs, and the results demonstrated that those MOFs with methyl, ethyl, or propyl functional groups exhibit the highest storage capacity. In addition, theoretical and experimental results have suggested that open metal sites could enhance the binding strength between CH4 and the host and hence increase methane storage capacity in MOF materials.

elements.content: Gas storage applications require large uptakes at relatively low pressures compared to compressed gas storage to give safety advantages. In gas storage applications on porous materials, thermodynamics are important because the isosteric enthalpy of adsorption at zero surface coverage is a fundamental measure of the strength of the gas interaction with the adsorbent. The variation of storage temperature in use is an issue since it leads to variation in adsorption capacities. Heat management issues require consideration since exothermic adsorption requires dissipation of heat and endothermic desorption results in cooling during gas supply to an engine, which could be a limiting factor. In the case of methane, both adsorption and desorption kinetics may be significant for methane because of the larger cross-section and kinetic diameter of methane compared with carbon dioxide may result in kinetic limitations. Storage capacity of porous materials can be enhanced by increasing pore volume by widening pores. An increase in pore width decreases the density of the material and this may have disadvantages for handling, use, and volumetric gas storage capacity. It also reduces the overlap of the potential energy fields of pore walls, and this leads to greater pressure required to obtain maximum uptake. The result is that many extremely porous MOFs with very large pores and low framework densities have relatively small volumetric gas storage capacities. Therefore, a compromise is required between adsorption pore volume and width in order to enhance uptake at relatively safe pressures. A promising strategy to further enhance gas storage capacity is to incorporate nanocages into the porous material, which have large enough windows for fast adsorption/desorption and size optimized for methane capacity. The ligand TMBDI = 2,3,5,6-tetramethylbenzene-1,4-diisophthalate, as shown in Figure a, has the appropriate length to form 16 Å diameter cages for adsorbing gas molecules. Also, the methyl groups, while occupying space and reducing pore volume compared with the corresponding benzene-1,4-diisophthalate structure, could act as components of the cage wall thereby enhancing uptake at low pressures. Previous work has shown that this ligand formed MOF NOTT-107, which has a triangular window viewing from [001] direction similar to that found in the series NOTT-101 to NOTT-107. The ligand was a suitable candidate for synthesizing MOFs with 16 Å nanocages, which are suitable for adsorption of 4 Å diameter spherical methane molecules with commensurate methane molecule packing in the spherical cages. Therefore, we investigated if other structures could be synthesized for gas storage by varying experimental conditions, solvent, temperature, etc.

elements.content: Most previous research on gas storage on porous materials has focused on the equilibrium gas adsorption properties rather than adsorption dynamics and diffusion through the porous structure, which is an important aspect for both gas storage and separation processes. In this article, the synthesis and structure of a nanoporous material Cu2(TMBDI)­(H2O)2 (NPC-4) incorporating interconnected cages, which has high methane and carbon dioxide adsorption storage characteristics, and excellent thermal stability, are described. The thermodynamics and transport diffusion of methane and carbon dioxide adsorption and desorption are discussed in detail, in relation to structural aspects involving surface barriers and intraparticle diffusion through windows and cages in the pore structure. Fundamental aspects of methane and carbon dioxide adsorption and desorption transport kinetics under high pressure for a porous material are critical for storage.

elements.content: 1,4-dibromo-2,3,5,6-tetramethylbenzene and 3,5-dimethylphenylboronic acid were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Inc. tert-Butanol ( t BuOH), tetrahydrofuran (THF), ethanol (EtOH), N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA), copper­(II) nitrate trihydrate (Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O), potassium permanganate (KMnO4), hydrochloric acid (HCl), and sodium hydroxide (NaOH) were purchased from Alfa Aesar and used as supplied. High-pure (99.999%) gases of nitrogen, hydrogen, methane, and carbon dioxide were provided by Qingdao Heli Gas Co., Ltd., China.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials Used

1,4-dibromo-2,3,5,6-tetramethylbenzene and 3,5-dimethylphenylboronic acid were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Inc. tert-Butanol ( t BuOH), tetrahydrofuran (THF), ethanol (EtOH), N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA), copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O), potassium permanganate (KMnO4), hydrochloric acid (HCl), and sodium hydroxide (NaOH) were purchased from Alfa Aesar and used as supplied. High-pure (99.999%) gases of nitrogen, hydrogen, methane, and carbon dioxide were provided by Qingdao Heli Gas Co., Ltd., China.

elements.content: NPC-4 was synthesized by solvothermal reaction of TMBDI and Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O in the solution of DMA and H2O with the addition of HNO3. TMBDI (0.092 g, 0.2 mmol) and Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O (0.096 g, 0.4 mmol) were dissolved in DMA/H2O (3:1, 24 mL), and then 2 mL of concentrated HNO3 was added. The resulting mixture was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container and was heated to 373 K for 72 h. After cooling to room temperature at a rate of 0.05 K min–1, the pure phase of blue crystals was obtained and separated by filtration. A typical scanning electron micrograph of the crystals is shown in (see Figure S2). Anal. Calcd (Found, %): C, 46.8 (47.2), H, 5.46 (5.65), N, 3.53 (3.62). IR (KBr): ν­(cm–1) = 1629 (vs), 1510 (w), 1433 (m), 1384 (vs), 1258 (m), 1183 (w), 1090 (w), 1047 (w), 919 (w), 874 (w), 773 (m), 731 (m) (see Figure S12, ). The compound was formulated as [Cu2(TMBDI)­(H2O)2]­(DMA)2.5(H2O)4 on the basis of single-crystal X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and elemental analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Materials Synthesis and Characterization

NPC-4 was synthesized by solvothermal reaction of TMBDI and Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O in the solution of DMA and H2O with the addition of HNO3. TMBDI (0.092 g, 0.2 mmol) and Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.096 g, 0.4 mmol) were dissolved in DMA/H2O (3:1, 24 mL), and then 2 mL of concentrated HNO3 was added. The resulting mixture was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container and was heated to 373 K for 72 h. After cooling to room temperature at a rate of 0.05 K min-1, the pure phase of blue crystals was obtained and separated by filtration. A typical scanning electron micrograph of the crystals is shown in  (see Figure S2). Anal. Calcd (Found, %): C, 46.8 (47.2), H, 5.46 (5.65), N, 3.53 (3.62). IR (KBr): ν(cm-1) = 1629 (vs), 1510 (w), 1433 (m), 1384 (vs), 1258 (m), 1183 (w), 1090 (w), 1047 (w), 919 (w), 874 (w), 773 (m), 731 (m) (see Figure S12, ). The compound was formulated as [Cu2(TMBDI)(H2O)2](DMA)2.5(H2O)4 on the basis of single-crystal X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and elemental analysis.

elements.content: Elemental analysis for C, H, and N were carried out on an Elementar Analysensysteme Vario EL cube instrument. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) measurements were performed on a Nicolet 6700 FTIR spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted on a Netzsch STA 449F3 unit at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 under a nitrogen atmosphere. Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were collected on a Bruker Avance-III NMR (600 MHz) spectrophotometer. SEM micrographs were taken using a Hitachi S-4800 scanning electron microscope with an accelerating voltage of 3 kV.

Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were collected on a Bruker Avance-III NMR (600 MHz) spectrophotometer. SEM micrographs were taken using a Hitachi S-4800 scanning electron microscope with an accelerating voltage of 3 kV.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction data of NPC-4 were collected at 293 K on a Bruker Smart APEX II charged couple device (CCD) area detector equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by difference Fourier techniques using the SHELXTL software package. Hydrogen atoms on the ligand were placed in idealized positions and refined using a riding model. Solvent molecules in the unit cell were highly disordered, which could not be modeled. To resolve these issues, the PLATON/SQUEEZE program was used to remove the contribution of solvent electron density.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Diffraction

Single crystal X-ray diffraction data of NPC-4 were collected at 293 K on a Bruker Smart APEX II charged couple device (CCD) area detector equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by difference Fourier techniques using the SHELXTL software package. Hydrogen atoms on the ligand were placed in idealized positions and refined using a riding model. Solvent molecules in the unit cell were highly disordered, which could not be modeled. To resolve these issues, the PLATON/SQUEEZE program was used to remove the contribution of solvent electron density.

elements.content:
Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was measured using a Bruker D8-Focus Bragg–Brentano X-ray Powder Diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm).

Gas Adsorption Methods

Gas adsorption isotherms were measured using an IGA gravimetric analyzer (Hiden Isochema, Warrington, UK). The system is an ultrahigh vacuum (UHV) system comprising a fully computer-controlled microbalance with both pressure and temperature regulation systems. The as-synthesized NPC-4 sample was acetone exchanged for 7 days prior to gas adsorption measurements to facilitate activation of the sample. About 100 mg of acetone-exchanged sample was introduced into the IGA for gas sorption measurements. This sample was outgassed to constant weight at <10–6 Pa and 393 K prior to adsorption measurements. The microbalance had a long-term stability of ±1 μg with a weighing resolution of 0.2 μg. The pressure transducers had ranges of 0–0.1 and 0–2 MPa. The set pressure point was maintained by computer control throughout the course of the experiment. The sample temperature was measured using a thermocouple located 5 mm from the sample. Nitrogen and hydrogen adsorption isotherms were performed at 77 K using a liquid nitrogen bath. Carbon dioxide and methane sorption isotherms were carried out using a circulating water/ethylene glycol bath (270–313 K) and 195 K (dry ice/acetone bath). The absolute isotherm for nitrogen was calculated using the buoyancy for the nitrogen adsorbate. The surface excess adsorption was determined for CO2, CH4, and H2 using the buoyancy correction based on the crystallographic density for the desolvated framework material. The repeatability of the methane high pressure adsorption isotherm at 290 K ranged from 0.55% at 0.399 bar to ±0.41% at 20 bar, while the repeatability for desorption was slightly higher (1.62% at 1 bar) (see , Figure S13a).

elements.content: Saturated vapor pressures were calculated using the Antoine equation: log ⁡ p 0 = A − B T + C where p 0 is the saturated vapor pressure (Torr), T is the temperature (K), and A, B, and C are adsorbate-dependent constants. The parameters used for each adsorptive are as follows: nitrogen (75–190 K) (A) 6.49457, (B), 255.68, (C) 266.550; and carbon dioxide (77–303 K) (A) 7.81024, (B) 995.705, (C) 293.475. The difference between surface excess and absolute amount adsorbed is non-negligible at high pressures. The absolute isotherm was calculated using the following equation. n abs = n ex + ρ b V ads where n abs is the absolute amount adsorbed, n ex is the surface excess, V ads is the PLATON pore volume, and ρb is the density of the gas phase. The gas phase densities for calculating the high pressure absolute isotherms were calculated using REFPROP, which uses the following equations of state (EOS): CO2 (Span and Wagner) and CH4 (Setzmann and Wagner).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis revealed that NPC-4 crystallizes in a tetragonal space group I4/mmm and exhibits a 3D framework structure containing 4-connected tetra-carboxylate ligands and paddle-wheel Cu2(COO)4 secondary building units (SBUs). The asymmetric unit of NPC-4 consists of one-quarter of the TMBDI ligand and one-eighth of the dinuclear paddle-wheel SBU (see Figures and S4, ). The sites in the equatorial plane of the paddle-wheel SBUs are linked by four carboxylate ligands, while the axial positions are occupied by two coordinated water molecules. A torsion angle of ∼22° was observed for the four carboxylate groups and isophthalate phenyl group of the TMBDI ligand (Figure S10, ), whereas in previously reported MOFs containing paddle-wheel Cu2(COO)4 SBUs, most of the carboxylate groups lie in the same plane with the isophthalate phenyl ring. The carboxylate groups rotate relative to the isophthalate phenyl ring to minimize network energy. The steric characteristics of the four methyl groups located on the central benzene ring result in the zygomorphic isophthalate groups roughly lying in the same plane, which is perpendicular to the plane of the central benzene ring.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Characteristics

Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis revealed that NPC-4 crystallizes in a tetragonal space group I4/mmm and exhibits a 3D framework structure containing 4-connected tetra-carboxylate ligands and paddle-wheel Cu2(COO)4 secondary building units (SBUs). The asymmetric unit of NPC-4 consists of one-quarter of the TMBDI ligand and one-eighth of the dinuclear paddle-wheel SBU (see Figures  and S4, ). The sites in the equatorial plane of the paddle-wheel SBUs are linked by four carboxylate ligands, while the axial positions are occupied by two coordinated water molecules. A torsion angle of ~22° was observed for the four carboxylate groups and isophthalate phenyl group of the TMBDI ligand (Figure S10, ), whereas in previously reported MOFs containing paddle-wheel Cu2(COO)4 SBUs, most of the carboxylate groups lie in the same plane with the isophthalate phenyl ring. The carboxylate groups rotate relative to the isophthalate phenyl ring to minimize network energy. The steric characteristics of the four methyl groups located on the central benzene ring result in the zygomorphic isophthalate groups roughly lying in the same plane, which is perpendicular to the plane of the central benzene ring.

elements.content: The assembly of the ligand and paddle-wheel SBUs resulted in a ssb or 42.84 topology, which was different from NbO type or 64.82 topology that is commonly adopted by most MOFs constructed from 4-connected ligands and SBUs. By simplifying the bridging ligands as double Y-shaped linkers and the paddle-wheel SBUs as square nodes, the structure of NPC-4 can be simplified into a ssb network (as shown in Figure b,e). The whole network can be viewed as the intersection of two honeycomb 2-D networks, which lie in two planes perpendicular to each other and cross-linked to form the three-dimensional network (as shown in Figure d,e). The framework of NPC-4 can also be viewed as a combination of closely arranged uniform nanoscale polyhedron cages, which are constructed by eight SBUs and 16 ligands, and the diameter is about 16 Å (as shown in Figures b and S5–S11, ). The methyl groups on the central benzene ring exactly locate on the wall surface of polyhedron cages (as shown in Figure b). Viewing from a or b axis, the rectangle window formed by two adjacent ligands is divided into two smaller windows by four methyl groups on the central benzene ring and windows with dimensions 5.2 × 6.3 Å, taking into account van der Waals radii. NPC-4 is a highly porous material comprising nanocages connected by windows with a total solvent accessible free volume calculated by PLATON program of ∼65% (0.781 cm3 g–1).

elements.content: The topology of NPC-4 is different from the previous reported MOF NOTT-107, which employs the same ligand and SBU, and this is caused by steric effects influencing the angle between the carboxylate group and isophthalate phenyl ring. A comparison of the two structures is shown in Figure S5a,b, . The powder X-ray diffraction profiles for NOTT-107 and NPC-4 (simulated and as-synthesized) are shown in Figure a. The structural differences of these two materials are shown in a view along the [001] direction with a square window with D 4h symmetry observed for NPC-4, which is clearly different from the type-I triangular windows with C 3 symmetry in NOTT-101–NOTT-108 (as shown in Figure b,c). Figure S5, , shows a comparison of NPC-4 and NOTT-107 viewed along the b and c crystallographic axes. The topology of NPC-4 is the same as that of NOTT-109. However, NOTT-109 employs a naphthalene derivative ligand, while NPC-4 uses the ligand TMBDI, which has methyl functional groups that enhance methane storage.

elements.content: The as-synthesized sample was solvent exchanged with acetone for 7 days. The thermogravimetric profiles for the as-synthesized and acetone-exchanged samples are shown in Figure . The TGA profiles show that the acetone-exchanged sample quickly reaches a plateau after fully losing coordinated water and remains stable up to 300 °C, whereas the as-synthesized sample lost solvent gradually. The exchange of the guest molecules in the framework with the more volatile acetone is helpful for completely removing the guests. The acetone-exchanged sample (about 100 mg) was activated at 393 K under ultrahigh vacuum for 4 h for adsorption studies, during which time the color of the MOF turned from blue to violet. This is attributed to loss of coordinated water/solvent molecules. PXRD confirmed the bulk purity and showed that it was crystalline even after activation at 120 °C and exposed to air. NPC-4 also remained crystalline after treatment with boiling water (see Figure S3, ), but the methane capacity was slightly lower. The pore structure of NPC-4 is stable for repeated adsorption/desorption cycles (see Figure S13a, )

elements.content: The nitrogen absolute isotherm of NPC-4 at 77 K exhibits typical reversible type-I shape in the IUPAC Classification Scheme with an uptake of 61.1 wt % at 1 bar (Figure a). The total pore volume (calculated using ρ­(N2) = 0.8081 g cm–3) and total void space ratio calculated for NPC-4 were 0.756 cm3 g–1 and 62.9%, respectively, which is consistent with the value (0.781 cm3 g–1) obtained from crystallographic data using PLATON, indicating that the guest molecules are completely removed during the activation process without framework collapse. This is supported by the TGA plot (Figure ) and PXRD profiles (Figure ). The BET graph has a slight curvature, and the surface area calculated from the N2 isotherm in low-pressure range (0.01 < p/p 0 < 0.085) was 1816 m2 g–1 (see , Figure S15), which is comparable to NOTT-107 and PCN-14, and the Langmuir surface area was 2130 m2 g–1 (see , Figure S16). The high value of the BET c parameter (1253) is indicative of micropore filling. H2 adsorption isotherm on NPC-4 at 77 K is given in Figure b. At 77 K and 1 bar, the uptake of H2 in NPC-4 was 2.3 wt % , and the surface excess of H2 for NPC-4 was 4.5 wt % at 77 K and 20 bar. The latter H2 uptake at 20 bar is similar to other materials with similar surface areas.

elements.clean_text:
High Pressure Adsorption Isotherms

Adsorption experiments measure the surface excess, and this is the amount adsorbed, which exceeds gas phase density. The absolute isotherm represents the actual adsorbed layer, and this is the quantity that must be considered rather than surface excess for high pressure adsorption experiments for determining adsorption storage capacities. The absolute isotherms were calculated from the surface excess isotherms (Figures c,d) and the crystallographic pore volume using eq . Comparisons of surface excess and absolute isotherms for CH4 and CO2 are shown in Figure S13b,c, .

elements.content: Figure c shows the subcritical CO2 surface excess adsorption isotherms for NPC-4 at 198, 273, and 303 K up to 20 bar. NPC-4 has a surface excess adsorption of 77.9 wt % (17.7 mmol g–1) of CO2 at 273 K, while at 303 K the surface excess adsorption was 64.9 wt % (14.75 mmol g–1) of CO2. At 198 K and 1 bar, the surface excess uptake for CO2 on NPC-4 was 87.8 wt % and close to saturation. Extrapolation of the absolute isotherm to p/p 0 = 1 using the Langmuir equation gave the total absolute uptake capacity of 88.1 wt %. The total pore volume derived from the CO2 absolute isotherm at 198 K was 0.749 cm3 g–1 (assuming the density of 1.177 g cm–3 for adsorbed CO2 in liquid form at 216.5 K), which is similar to the total pore volume (0.756 cm3 g–1) determined from N2 adsorption at 77 K. The pore space ratio was 61.2% (using the crystallographic density of 0.832 g cm–3 for NPC-4). The Langmuir equation was also used to extrapolate the CO2 absolute adsorption data at 273 and 303 K for pressure range 10–20 bar. At p/p 0 = 1 the maximum uptakes were 87.4 and 81.5 wt % and these values are similar to the value obtained for the 198 K data where the maximum correction for the conversion of surface excess to absolute adsorption was <0.3% (see Figure S13b, ). The CO2 adsorption data are compared with various high capacity MOFs in Table . The results for CO2 adsorbate density of NPC-4 suggest a small decrease with increasing temperature similar to the changes in liquid CO2 density, which decrease from 1.177 g cm–3 at 216.6 K to 0.762 g cm–3 at 294.3 K. Also, the adsorbed CO2 at 303 K is denser than liquid CO2 at 294.3 K suggesting that the cage structure enhances adsorbate density. The subcritical CO2 isotherms at 298 K for the very low density materials (MOF-200 and MOF-210), where the saturation vapor pressure is ∼64.3 bar, have CO2 densities in the pores in the range 0.79–0.80 at 50 bar (Table ), which is similar to liquid CO2 at 294.3 K.

High resolution carbon dioxide isotherms were measured in the low pressure region (≤1 bar) in order to establish if differences in interaction energies due to surface chemistry, in particular, unsaturated metal sites, could be observed in adsorption thermodynamics as a function of amount adsorbed. The CO2 isotherms at 273–313 K in the low pressure range are given in the (Figure S14a). The isotherms were analyzed using the virial equation below ln ( n / p ) = A 0 + A 1 n + A 2 n 2 ... where p is the pressure, n is the amount absorbed, and A 0, A 1, A 2, etc., are virial coefficients. At low surface coverage the higher terms (A2, A3, etc.) can be neglected, and a graph of ln­(n/p) versus n gives a straight line. A 0 describes adsorbate–adsorbent interaction, while A 1 describes adsorbate–adsorbate interactions. The A 1 virial values for CO2 adsorption on NPC-4 over the temperature range 273–313 K are in the range −17 to −40 g mol–1 (Figure S23, ). These values are much lower than (−1000 to −1045) g mol–1 found for carbon molecular sieves used for air separation, (−940 to −1070 g mol–1) for M′MOF 2a, and (−1902 to −3117 g mol–1) for M′MOF3a. These smaller values observed in this study are a result of lower adsorbate–adsorbate interactions in the larger pore nanocages of NPC-4 at low surface coverage (<2 mmol g–1). The isosteric enthalpy at zero surface coverage (Q st,n=0),which is a fundamental measure of the CO2 interaction with NPC-4, was obtained from a graph of A 0 versus 1/T, and the value was 23.17 ± 0.10 kJ mol–1 for 273–313 K (Figure S24, ).

elements.content: In the case of high pressure adsorption, the isosteric adsorption enthalpies (Q st,n) as a function of amount adsorbed were calculated using both the Gibbs surface excess and absolute isotherms. The former is a partition rather than a phase, whereas the latter describes the actual adsorbed phase. There is controversy over the calculation of thermodynamic parameters from high pressure adsorption data. Therefore, the parameters have been calculated from both the excess and absolute isotherms. CO2 absolute adsorption isotherms for NPC-4 at 198, 273, and 303 K (see the calculation details in , Section S9, Table S2) were used. Figure a shows that the Q st,n values do not vary significantly with amount adsorbed, while entropy of adsorption (Δ S n) decreases with increasing surface coverage. The isosteric adsorption enthalpies of CO2 in NPC-4 were in the range of 24.5–25.5 kJ mol–1 for absolute uptakes of 0.5–15.5 mmol g–1 (Table S2, ). The corresponding isosteric enthalpies calculated from the surface excess data were similar at low uptake and pressure and were <1 kJ mol–1 higher at high pressure and surface excess of 14.5 mmol g–1 , where the correction for conversion of surface excess to absolute isotherms is larger (see Figure S20, ). Isosteric enthalpies of adsorption of CO2 on NPC-4 calculated from both isotherm types had a maximum difference of 2.4% at 14.5 mmol g–1 (26.08 ± 0.88 kJ mol–1 (surface excess) and 25.47 ± 1.1 kJ mol–1 (absolute)).

elements.content: The isosteric enthalpy for CO2 adsorption was also investigated at low surface coverage using high resolution absolute isotherms at 273, 283, 293, 303, and 313 K in order to establish if the presence of unsaturated copper centers influenced the thermodynamics at low surface coverage. Q st,n ranged from 23.17 ± 0.10 kJ mol–1 at zero surface coverage (see Figure S24, ) to 23.39 ± 0.08 kJ mol–1 at 1 mmol g–1 (see Table S3, ). It is apparent that the isosteric enthalpies do not vary significantly with surface coverage, and therefore, the presence of unsaturated metal centers does not have a significant effect on Q st,n for adsorption of CO2 on NPC-4. Similar trends for CO2 adsorption have been reported for SIFSIX-2-Cu-1­(32–35 kJ mol–1) and SIFSIX-3-Zn (45 kJ mol –1) in the low pressure region (<2.5 mmol g–1). The isosteric enthalpies for CO2 adsorption on NPC-4 are similar to those obtained for MOF NOTT-202 (20–24 kJ mol–1) and porous carbon molecular sieves (28.4 ± 0.7 kJ mol–1).

elements.content: Methane supercritical adsorption measurements were performed at 195, 270, 280, and 290 K over the pressure range of 0–20 bar. The volumetric storage capacities expressed in v(STP)v c –1 where v c is the volume of crystal, were calculated using the crystallographic density of NPC-4 (0.832 g cm–3). At 290 K and 20 bar, the surface excess uptake of methane in NPC-4 was 14.7 wt % (as shown in Figure d) and the absolute amount adsorbed was 15.8 wt %, which corresponds to 183 v(STP)v c –1, and has not reached saturation at 20 bar, the pressure limit of the instrument. Table compares the methane storage capacities of NPC-4 and some previous reported MOFs under specific conditions. The methane surface excess at 290 K and 20 bar is slightly lower than the value of PCN-14 at 290 K and 35 bar. Therefore, the methane uptake capacity at 35 bar was calculated using the Langmuir equation, which fits the absolute isotherm data well (see Figures S29 and S30, ) and gave consistent results for the CO2 data. The predicted absolute uptake capacity of methane is 19.1 wt % at 290 K and 35 bar. This corresponds to 222 v(STP)v c –1 at 290 K and 35 bar and surpasses the DOE target of 180 v(STP)v –1 at 35 bar. The results are compared with selected methane storage capacities for some MOFs reported in the literature in Table . NPC-4 provides a good compromise between adsorbent density and pore volume to give an excellent capacity on a volumetric basis. At 290 K and 20 bar, the methane storage density in NPC-4 was 0.202 g cm–3, corresponding to the density of compressed methane at 290 K and ∼260 bar, while at 195 K and 20 bar, absolute amount of methane adsorbed was 27.9 wt % on NPC-4, corresponding to a methane storage density of 0.356 g cm–3, which is ∼84% of the storage of liquid methane (0.425 g cm–3 at 111.7 K) in NPC-4 porosity. Methane adsorption in PCN-14 at 125 K showed that it had an adsorbed methane density of 0.31 g cm–3. The methane storage density at 150 K and 5 bar was 0.376 g cm–3 for UTSA-20. A decrease in adsorbed phase density is expected with increasing temperature. Table shows that MOF-200 and MOF-210 have much lower CH4 adsorbate densities (0.124–0.132 g cm3) at 80 bar and 298 K compared with NPC-4 at 20 bar and 290 K. It is apparent that supercritical adsorption requires a much higher pressure to increase the adsorbed phase density.

Methane supercritical adsorption measurements were performed at 195, 270, 280, and 290 K over the pressure range of 0-20 bar. The volumetric storage capacities expressed in v(STP)v c -1 where v c is the volume of crystal, were calculated using the crystallographic density of NPC-4 (0.832 g cm-3). At 290 K and 20 bar, the surface excess uptake of methane in NPC-4 was 14.7 wt % (as shown in Figure d) and the absolute amount adsorbed was 15.8 wt %, which corresponds to 183 v(STP)v c -1, and has not reached saturation at 20 bar, the pressure limit of the instrument. Table  compares the methane storage capacities of NPC-4 and some previous reported MOFs under specific conditions. The methane surface excess at 290 K and 20 bar is slightly lower than the value of PCN-14 at 290 K and 35 bar. Therefore, the methane uptake capacity at 35 bar was calculated using the Langmuir equation, which fits the absolute isotherm data well (see Figures S29 and S30, ) and gave consistent results for the CO2 data. The predicted absolute uptake capacity of methane is 19.1 wt % at 290 K and 35 bar. This corresponds to 222 v(STP)v c -1 at 290 K and 35 bar and surpasses the DOE target of 180 v(STP)v -1 at 35 bar. The results are compared with selected methane storage capacities for some MOFs reported in the literature in Table . NPC-4 provides a good compromise between adsorbent density and pore volume to give an excellent capacity on a volumetric basis. At 290 K and 20 bar, the methane storage density in NPC-4 was 0.202 g cm-3, corresponding to the density of compressed methane at 290 K and ~260 bar, while at 195 K and 20 bar, absolute amount of methane adsorbed was 27.9 wt % on NPC-4, corresponding to a methane storage density of 0.356 g cm-3, which is ~84% of the storage of liquid methane (0.425 g cm-3 at 111.7 K) in NPC-4 porosity. Methane adsorption in PCN-14 at 125 K showed that it had an adsorbed methane density of 0.31 g cm-3. The methane storage density at 150 K and 5 bar was 0.376 g cm-3 for UTSA-20. A decrease in adsorbed phase density is expected with increasing temperature. Table  shows that MOF-200 and MOF-210 have much lower CH4 adsorbate densities (0.124-0.132 g cm3) at 80 bar and 298 K compared with NPC-4 at 20 bar and 290 K. It is apparent that supercritical adsorption requires a much higher pressure to increase the adsorbed phase density.

Methane uptake capacities at 290 K and 35 bar in NPC-4 were predicted using the Langmuir equation using the absolute CH4 isotherm data for 10–20 bar.

The gravimetric methane uptake capacity in UTSA-20 is calculated by multiplying the density of adsorbed CH4 with the pore volume of UTSA-20.

The adsorbate–adsorbate interactions were quantified by a virial analysis of the methane adsorption isotherms for temperature range 195–290 K. The A 1 virial values for CH4 adsorption on NPC-4 over this temperature range were −85 ± 2.6 g mol–1 (up to 6.5 mmol g–1 at 195 K) to −120 ± 2.3 g mol–1 (up to 1.4 mmol g–1) at 280 K (see Figure S21a–d, ). These values are much lower than those reported for CH4 adsorption on a carbon molecular sieve (CMSA) used for air separation, where values in the range from −936 ± 38 to −899 ± 18 g mol–1 for temperatures in the range 338–358 K. It is evident that CH4–CH4 interactions in NPC-4 are much smaller and that this is attributed to the large diameter (16 Å) of the nanocages compared to the ultramicroporosity in carbon molecular sieves.

elements.content: In practical methane storage applications both thermal and kinetic effects need to be considered. The thermal heat generated in adsorption and cooling during desorption lead to a requirement for a relatively low enthalpy consistent with a high storage capacity. The isosteric adsorption enthalpy (Q st,n=0) of methane was analyzed using the virial methods to obtain the value at zero surface coverage and the isosteres to obtain Q st,n values at various amounts adsorbed (see details in , section S9, Figure S22a,b, and Table S4). The Q st,n for methane adsorption on NPC-4 lies in the range of 15–15.5 kJ mol–1 for absolute amounts adsorbed in the range 1–9.5 mmol g–1. The maximum difference in the Q st , n values, calculated from the excess and absolute isotherms, was 4.1% at 9 mmol g–1 (15.86 ± 0.11 kJ mol–1 (surface excess) and 15.19 ± 0.17 kJ mol–1 (absolute)). The Q st,n values from the excess isotherm are slightly higher than the corresponding value obtained from the absolute isotherms (see Figure S20, ). The enthalpy at zero coverage was 15.18 ± 0.09 kJ mol–1 (195–290 K) (see Figure S22b, ) and slightly lower than those MOFs exhibiting high methane uptake capacity and 23.8 ± 1.1 kJ mol–1 observed for carbon molecular sieves. The lower values for Q st,n are attributed to the wide nanocage structure.

elements.content: In storage applications it is important to establish the extent to which adsorption capacity varies with temperature since this is a variable during use, which can influence the deliverable capacity. In order to quantify these characteristics, adsorption isobars were modeled by various equations. In adsorption experiments the surface excess is measured, and at high pressure, the surface excess is significantly lower than the absolute isotherm. The surface excess for both methane and carbon dioxide adsorption follow an approximately linear relationship with 1/temperature (K) as observed for CH4 surface excess adsorption on shales (temperature range 300–473 K). Several adsorption isobar equations have been reported. Iliin proposed an isobar equation n = k 1 exp ( − k 2 T ) where n is amount adsorbed, k 1 and k 2 are constants, and T is temperature (K). The equation indicates that a graph of ln­(n) versus √T should be linear. Linear graphs were observed for CO2 absolute isotherms for uptakes <7 mmol g–1 (pressure < 1 bar pressure and temperatures in the range 273–313 K (R 2 = 0.9926–0.9999)) and CH4 absolute isotherms for (uptakes <11.5 mmol g–1 (pressure up to 20 bar and temperature range 270–290 K (R 2 = 0.9974–0.9995)) (see Figure for typical isobars). The corresponding isobar graphs for the 198–290 K show some evidence for a small amount of curvature. It is evident that the variation in amount adsorbed at constant pressure can be modeled accurately over a reasonable temperature range for gas storage applications.

elements.content: Gas separation can be achieved by both equilibrium and kinetic mechanisms. CO2/CH4 equilibrium selectivity has been observed for a number of MOFs at temperatures in the range 195–303 K, and these include MIL-53, zeolitic imidazolate framework, cobalt adeniate frameworks, and carbon molecular sieves. Previous studies of interpenetrated MOF NOTT 202a have shown similar CO2/CH4 ratios. However, in NOTT 202a, the CO2 desorption isotherm below 60 mbar gives rise to an effective trapping and capture mechanism for CO2. CO2/CH4 selectivity has been observed for interpenetrated MOFs at 195 K due to a micropore gating effect. Enhancement of CO2 selectivity in a pillared [Cu­(bipy)2·(SiF6)] platform may be achieved through pillar substitution. Also, pore size and surface polarization may be fine-tuned in MOFs to enhance CO2 selectivity.
elements.clean_text:
Selectivity for CH4 and CO2 

Gas separation can be achieved by both equilibrium and kinetic mechanisms. CO2/CH4 equilibrium selectivity has been observed for a number of MOFs at temperatures in the range 195-303 K, and these include MIL-53, zeolitic imidazolate framework, cobalt adeniate frameworks, and carbon molecular sieves. Previous studies of interpenetrated  MOF NOTT 202a have shown similar CO2/CH4 ratios. However, in NOTT 202a, the CO2 desorption isotherm below 60 mbar gives rise to an effective trapping and capture mechanism for CO2. CO2/CH4 selectivity has been observed for interpenetrated MOFs at 195 K due to a micropore gating effect. Enhancement of CO2 selectivity in a pillared [Cu(bipy)2⋅(SiF6)] platform may be achieved through pillar substitution. Also, pore size and surface polarization may be fine-tuned in MOFs to enhance CO2 selectivity.

elements.content: At 195 K, below the CO2 triple point, the CO2/CH4 uptake ratio for NPC-4 for adsorption was ∼10 and ∼2 on a mole basis, at 100 mbar and 1 bar, respectively. At 290 K, the CO2/CH4 uptake ratio was ∼3 and ∼1.2 on a mole basis at 1 and 20 bar, respectively. This is explained by micropore filling occurring at low temperature for subcritical adsorption of CO2, whereas CH4 adsorption is under supercritical conditions, where micropore filling occurs to a lower extent. At 290 K and 1 bar, the relative pressure for CO2 is much lower and hence the amount adsorbed is lower, leading to a lower CO2/CH4 ratio.

At 290 K, the CO2/CH4 uptake ratio was ~3 and ~1.2 on a mole basis at 1 and 20 bar, respectively. This is explained by micropore filling occurring at low temperature for subcritical adsorption of CO2, whereas CH4 adsorption is under supercritical conditions, where micropore filling occurs to a lower extent. At 290 K and 1 bar, the relative pressure for CO2 is much lower and hence the amount adsorbed is lower, leading to a lower CO2/CH4 ratio.

elements.content: The adsorption and desorption kinetics also need to be considered in storage applications for charging and discharging gases during operation. Diffusion of molecules into porous structures may be influenced by molecular sieving through constrictions in the pore structure, surface barriers, and surface chemistry via surface diffusion with a site-to-site hopping mechanism. Molecular sieving depends on the critical dimension(s) of the adsorbate relative to the shapes and sizes of pores. In the case of slit shaped pores, one dimension is critical, whereas for circular pores there are two critical dimensions. NPC-4 has nanocages with diameter 16 Å connected by rectangular windows with dimensions of 5.2 × 6.3 Å. Surface diffusion is controlled by adsorbate–adsorbent and adsorbate–adsorbate interactions and related to the enthalpy of adsorption. In the case of H2 (kinetic diameter 2.89 Å), adsorption is normally very fast. CO2 has dimensions of 3.339 × 3.189 × 5.361 Å, derived from ZINDO calculations, which indicates a small cross section. However, methane has dimensions of ∼4 Å (3.829 × 3.942 × 4.101 Å) and 3.24–4.57 Å and a kinetic diameter of 3.8 Å. The similarity between the CH4 and window (5.2 × 6.3 Å) dimensions in NPC-4 suggest that kinetic limitations due to molecular sieving effects might occur, but CO2 has smaller cross section dimensions and therefore should be less influenced by diffusion through the windows in the structure.
elements.clean_text:
Adsorption Kinetics

The adsorption and desorption kinetics also need to be considered in storage applications for charging and discharging gases during operation. Diffusion of molecules into porous structures may be influenced by molecular sieving through constrictions in the pore structure, surface barriers, and surface chemistry via surface diffusion with a site-to-site hopping mechanism. Molecular sieving depends on the critical dimension(s) of the adsorbate relative to the shapes and sizes of pores. In the case of slit shaped pores, one dimension is critical, whereas for circular pores there are two critical dimensions. NPC-4 has nanocages with diameter 16 Å connected by rectangular windows with dimensions of 5.2 × 6.3 Å. Surface diffusion is controlled by adsorbate-adsorbent and adsorbate-adsorbate interactions and related to the enthalpy of adsorption. In the case of H2 (kinetic diameter 2.89 Å), adsorption is normally very fast. CO2 has dimensions of 3.339 × 3.189 × 5.361 Å, derived from ZINDO calculations, which indicates a small cross section. However, methane has dimensions of ~4 Å (3.829 × 3.942 × 4.101 Å) and 3.24-4.57 Å and a kinetic diameter of 3.8 Å. The similarity between the CH4 and window (5.2 × 6.3 Å) dimensions in NPC-4 suggest that kinetic limitations due to molecular sieving effects might occur, but CO2 has smaller cross section dimensions and therefore should be less influenced by diffusion through the windows in the structure.

elements.content: Linear driving force (LDF) combined with barrier resistance/Fickian diffusion, Fickian, and stretched exponential models have been used to describe diffusion of molecules into porous particles. The LDF model describes the adsorption/desorption kinetic profiles when diffusion through a surface layer is the rate determining process and is described by the following equation: M t M e = 1 − e − k t where M t is mass uptake at time t, M e is mass uptake at equilibrium, and k is the mass transfer rate constant. The adsorption kinetics can be compared using the rate constants (k) determined either from the gradients of graphs of ln­(1 – M t/M e ) versus time or by fitting the adsorption uptake curves to eq . Some of the kinetic profiles for both methane and carbon dioxide adsorption on NPC-4 follow the LDF model as shown by the linearity of the ln­(1 – M t/M e) against time graph for pressure increment 400–500 mbar for CO2 adsorption at 273 K (see Figure a).

elements.content: Diffusivity is measured when internal diffusion controls the adsorption/desorption kinetic profiles. Fick’s law for isothermal diffusion into a homogeneous sphere is given by the following equation: M t M e = 1 − 6 π 2 ∑ n = 1 ∞ ( 1 n 2 ) exp ( − Dn 2 π 2 t r 2 ) where M t is mass uptake at time t, M e is mass uptake at equilibrium, D is diffusivity, and r is radius of the particle. The series in the above equation converges very rapidly and a graph of ln­(1 – M t/M e) versus time is close to linearity in the uptake region M t /M e > 0.6. Therefore, the graph only differs from the LDF model in the initial uptake region where M t /M e < 0.6. Fickian diffusion was observed for NPC-4 at low uptake/pressure and where kinetic measurements were sufficiently slow to allow accurate measurements. The kinetic profile for CH4 adsorption on NPC-4 at 195 K for pressure increment 20–50 mbar is shown in Figure b. It is evident that eq for Fickian diffusion into a sphere gives a good fit for the kinetic profile with D = 1.0432 × 10–12 m2 s–1 assuming particle radius of 3 × 10–5 m. Fickian kinetic profiles were also observed for CO2 adsorption for pressure increments between 80 and 200 mbar at 273 K (see , Figure S34a,b).

elements.content: The combined barrier resistance/diffusion (CBRD) model is based on the assumption of the presence of a surface barrier resistance and subsequent diffusion in a spherical microporous system by Fick’s law. The equations for isothermal diffusion into a spherical particle with this model are as follows: ∂ C ∂ t = D [ ( ∂ 2 C ∂ r 2 ) + ( 2 r ) ( ∂ C ∂ r ) ] where D is the crystallite diffusivity (m2 s–1), C is the sorbate concentration in the crystallite (mmol m–3), r is the radial coordinate, and t is the time. D ∂ C ( r c t ) ∂ r = k b ( C * ( t ) − C ( r , t ) ) where D is the crystallite diffusivity (m2 s–1), k b is the surface barrier resistance (m s–1), r is the radial coordinate, r c is the radius of the crystallite (m), t is time(s), C is the sorbate concentration in the crystallite (mol m–3), and C* is the surface concentration in equilibrium with the gas phase (mol m–3). The parameters derived from the model are k b the barrier resistance constant and k d resistance due to diffusion in the pores. A full description of the method used for solving the equation has been described previously. Figure c,d shows typical examples of kinetic profiles for both CO2 and CH4 adsorption and the CBRD descriptions of the profiles assuming spherical particle shape with a radius of 3 × 10–5 m. Additional kinetic profiles are given in , Figures S33–S39. It is evident that the CBRD model provides a good fit for these kinetic profiles.

elements.content: Surface diffusion of molecules is an activated process involving hopping between adjacent sites and is affected by interaction between the adsorbed molecule and surface sites. In the case of small pores, electrostatic interaction and steric effects become important and may result in very large differences in molecular diffusivity for similar molecules. Klafter and Shlesinger showed that the stretched exponential (SE) model is a common underlying mathematical structure relating the Forster direct-transfer mechanism, which involves relaxation via parallel channels and the serial hierarchically constrained dynamics and defect-diffusion models. The unifying mathematical feature of the models is a scale-invariant distribution of relaxation times. Surface diffusion of molecules constrained in pores has similar characteristics. The SE model is described by the following equation: M t M e = 1 − e − ( k t ) β where M t is the mass at time t, M e is the mass at equilibrium, k is the mass transfer rate constant (s–1), and t is the time(s). The exponent parameter (β) is material-dependent and reflects the width of the distribution of relaxation times. The SE model is 3-dimensional with a single relaxation time when β = 1 (linear driving force (LDF) model) and 1-dimensonal with a distribution of relaxation times when β = 0.5.

elements.content: There are similarities in models based on molecular surface diffusion and macroscopic diffusion into particles. The SE model fits theoretical Fickian diffusion profiles described by eqs and (see , Figure S31a,b). Figure b shows a comparison of Fickian and stretched exponential fitting of the kinetic profile for 20–50 mbar CH4 pressure increment. The stretched exponential model provides a good fit for experimental profile in Figure b with β = 0.638 ± 0.005 and k = 0.0230 ± 0.0002 s–1 (R 2 = 0.994) as does Fickian eq , which assumes spherical-shaped particles. Typical examples of SE model descriptions for adsorption kinetic profiles for CO2 and CH4 adsorption, which are intermediate between Fickian and LDF, are shown in Figure e–g and for desorption profiles in Figure h. Therefore, the stretched exponential model can describe the range of kinetic profiles with the exponent β quantifying the shape of the kinetic profile in comparison to Fickian (β ≈ 0.65) and LDF (β = 1). The adsorption kinetic profiles for pressure increments 8–9 bar for CO2 adsorption at 303 K and CH4 adsorption at 290 K on NPC-4 are shown in Figure e,f, respectively. Comparison of these profiles shows that CH4 adsorption is faster than CO2 despite the latter being carried out at a higher temperature. The normalized adsorption and desorption kinetic profiles for 400–600 mbar adsorption increment and 600–400 mbar desorption decrement of CH4 on NPC-4 at 195 K are shown in Figure g,h. These profiles show that the kinetic parameters are very similar for adsorption and desorption.
elements.clean_text: There are similarities in models based on molecular surface diffusion and macroscopic diffusion into particles. The SE model fits theoretical Fickian diffusion profiles described by eqs  and  (see , Figure S31a,b). Figure b shows a comparison of Fickian and stretched exponential fitting of the kinetic profile for 20-50 mbar CH4 pressure increment. The stretched exponential model provides a good fit for experimental profile in Figure b with β = 0.638 ± 0.005 and k = 0.0230 ± 0.0002 s-1 (R 2 = 0.994) as does Fickian eq , which assumes spherical-shaped particles. Typical examples of SE model descriptions for adsorption kinetic profiles for CO2 and CH4 adsorption, which are intermediate between Fickian and LDF, are shown in Figure e-g and for desorption profiles in Figure h. Therefore, the stretched exponential model can describe the range of kinetic profiles with the exponent β quantifying the shape of the kinetic profile in comparison to Fickian (β ~ 0.65) and LDF (β = 1). The adsorption kinetic profiles for pressure increments 8-9 bar for CO2 adsorption at 303 K and CH4 adsorption at 290 K on NPC-4 are shown in Figure e,f, respectively. Comparison of these profiles shows that CH4 adsorption is faster than CO2 despite the latter being carried out at a higher temperature. The normalized adsorption and desorption kinetic profiles for 400-600 mbar adsorption increment and 600-400 mbar desorption decrement of CH4 on NPC-4 at 195 K are shown in Figure g,h. These profiles show that the kinetic parameters are very similar for adsorption and desorption.

elements.content: A stretched exponential model has been used to describe the adsorption and desorption kinetics of a wide range of gases and vapors on metal–organic framework materials and activated carbons. Hence, the SE model has a wide applicability for studying adsorption dynamics for porous materials with widely different particle shapes. This model can serve as a link between models based on diffusion into particles and surface diffusion of molecules with hierarchical scale invariant properties. Previous studies of MOFs with windows in pores have shown that the adsorption kinetics can be described by either double exponential or double stretched exponential models corresponding to two processes: (a) diffusion through barriers due to narrow windows with a high activation energy and (b) diffusion along the pores with a lower barrier to diffusion and also diffusion along two types of pores with different shapes.
elements.clean_text: A stretched exponential model has been used to describe the adsorption and desorption kinetics of a wide range of gases and vapors on metal-organic framework materials and activated carbons. Hence, the SE model has a wide applicability for studying adsorption dynamics for porous materials with widely different particle shapes. This model can serve as a link between models based on diffusion into particles and surface diffusion of molecules with hierarchical scale invariant properties. Previous studies of MOFs with windows in pores have shown that the adsorption kinetics can be described by either double exponential or double stretched exponential models corresponding to two processes: (a) diffusion through barriers due to narrow windows with a high activation energy and (b) diffusion along the pores with a lower barrier to diffusion and also diffusion along two types of pores with different shapes.

elements.content: In real systems, particle size distributions and irregular particle shapes may make the determination of diffusion coefficients difficult. NPC-4 is very stable allowing repeat adsorption measurements on the same sample (see Figure S13a, for CH4 measurements) and high reproducibility between samples. In this study all adsorption studies were carried out on the same sample so that particle shape and size distribution factors do not vary thereby allowing direct comparisons of kinetic profiles for various pressure increments. The kinetic profiles for each adsorption isotherm pressure increment and corresponding desorption isotherm decrement were measured for small pressure increments and decrements, where the diffusivities may be considered constant, to understand the dynamics associated with the adsorption isotherms. In NPC-4, the adsorption at very low uptakes (<1 mmol g–1) was too fast to be determined accurately by the gravimetric methods used in this study. Temperature only had a small effect on the adsorption kinetics, and therefore, a wide temperature range was used in order to quantify the activation energies and enthalpies of activation.

elements.content: The values of the LDF intraparticle mass transfer coefficient (k) can be converted to effective intraparticle diffusion coefficients (D c) using the equation below: k = 15 D c / r 2 where r is the radius of the particle. The NPC-4 crystals used have some variation in size and shape. Typically the crystals had a cross section diameter of ∼60 μm (see Figure S2, ), and this was used in the calculation of diffusion coefficients. D c values were in the range 6 × 10–13–2.4 × 10–12 m2 s–1 (195–290 K and uptakes > ∼2 mmol g–1) for methane and 1.8 × 10–13–1.1 × 10–12 m2 s–1 (198–303 K and uptakes > 2 mmol g–1) for CO2. Similar values for diffusion parameters obtained were obtained from Fickian and CBRD models.

elements.content: The values of the diffusion coefficients for CO2 for MOF-5 and CPM-5 were 8.1–11.5 × 10–13 m2 s–1 for 295–331 K and 1.86–7.97 ×10–12 m2 s–1 for 273–318 K, respectively. The CO2 diffusion coefficients for NPC-4 are similar to those for MOF-5 in the temperature range 273–303 K. Studies of adsorption on ZIF8 showed that diffusivities were higher (CO2 < 5 × 10–10 m2 s–1; CH4 < 2.5 × 10–9 m2 s–1) and varied with loading. Studies of CH4 adsorption on various DDR zeolite crystals have given values for intracrystalline diffusivity of 5.5 × 10–13–2.3 × 10–12 m2 s–1 (273–423 K), while other reports give similar values. The self-diffusion coefficients for CO2 and CH4 on ZSM-58 (DDR topology) were 6.5 × 10–10 m2 s–1 and 1.03 × 10–11 m2 s–1, respectively. It is evident that the values of diffusivities determined in this study are similar to values reported in the literature.

elements.content: The variation of the SE rate constants for CO2 adsorption as a function of amount adsorbed shows that the SE rate constants decrease markedly up to about 3 mmol g–1 but are fairly constant for 3–15 mmol g–1 (see Figure a). Since the CO2 adsorption is subcritical, the kinetic profiles can be compared over the full uptake range. At 198 K, the rate constants increase progressively from a minimum at 12 mmol g–1 to 19.8 mmol g–1.
elements.clean_text:
Adsorption Kinetics versus Amount Adsorbed

The variation of the SE rate constants for CO2 adsorption as a function of amount adsorbed shows that the SE rate constants decrease markedly up to about 3 mmol g-1 but are fairly constant for 3-15 mmol g-1 (see Figure a). Since the CO2 adsorption is subcritical, the kinetic profiles can be compared over the full uptake range. At 198 K, the rate constants increase progressively from a minimum at 12 mmol g-1 to 19.8 mmol g-1.

elements.content: The kinetic profiles for CH4 supercritical adsorption also follow the SE model at low pressure/uptake with the exponent β = ∼0.7–0.8, and this increases with increasing uptake becoming close to LDF (β = 1) for uptakes >8 mmol g–1 (see , Figure S32b). The variation of the SE adsorption rate constants as a function of amount adsorbed is given in Figure b. The SE kinetic rate constants only change to a small extent with increasing pressure, and the trend is influenced from the change from SE exponent (β) of ∼0.64 (Fickian) to ∼1 (linear driving force) at pressure increments above 1.5 bar.
elements.clean_text: The kinetic profiles for CH4 supercritical adsorption also follow the SE model at low pressure/uptake with the exponent β = ~0.7-0.8, and this increases with increasing uptake becoming close to LDF (β = 1) for uptakes >8 mmol g-1 (see , Figure S32b). The variation of the SE adsorption rate constants as a function of amount adsorbed is given in Figure b. The SE kinetic rate constants only change to a small extent with increasing pressure, and the trend is influenced from the change from SE exponent (β) of ~0.64 (Fickian) to ~1 (linear driving force) at pressure increments above 1.5 bar.

elements.content: The kinetic profiles can also be described by the CBRD model (see Figures c,d and S33−S39, ). The adsorption kinetic results for CO2 and CH4 adsorption on NPC-4 as a function of amount adsorbed are shown in Figure c,d, respectively, and regions of Fickian, CBRD, and LDF behavior are marked. At low uptakes the adsorption kinetics are fast, and the CH4 kinetic profile for 20–50 mbar can be described by a Fickian model for diffusion along pores (Figure b). Similar Fickian profiles for CO2 adsorption at 273 K are shown in , Figure S34a,b. In the case of CO2 adsorption at 198 and 273 K, the kinetic profiles change from Fickian through CBRD to LDF at 273 K and from CBRD to LDF at 198 K, with increasing uptake. The adsorption kinetic profiles at 303 K mainly follow the CBRD model (see Figure S35, ). The CBRD surface resistance barrier (k b) constant for CH4 adsorption initially decreases with increasing surface coverage, reaches a minimum at ∼11 mmol g–1, and increases thereafter (see Figure d). This trend is attributed to increasing surface barrier resistance due to increasing interactions between adsorbed molecules. At high pressure/uptakes, the adsorption kinetic profiles obey the LDF model indicating that the adsorption kinetics are limited by a surface resistance barrier to diffusion. It is apparent that diffusion along the pores is rate determining at low uptake, while a surface barrier becomes increasingly significant with increasing uptake and is rate determining at high uptake. The surface layer barrier is a result of structural differences due to surface termination and reconstruction effects.

elements.content: Kinetic limitations are a factor that needs to be considered for both methane and carbon dioxide adsorption on NPC-4 and other MOFs for storage applications. The times to reach equilibration at high pressure for each pressure increment are typically 5 min for CH4, with ∼90% uptake within 2 min, and may be a limitation for storage applications. The relative low adsorption enthalpy for NPC-4 allows fast surface diffusion and low heat transfer effects, which are a benefit for methane storage under ambient conditions. The high methane storage capacity of NPC-4 supports the viewpoint that introduction of methyl groups to optimize pore cage structure will increase methane storage capacity at low pressure in MOF materials.

elements.content: In the context of storage applications, it is useful to establish the effects of pressure and temperature on adsorption and desorption kinetics. Comparison of the normalized kinetic profiles pressure steps 1.5–2 and 10–11 bar for 195, 270, 280, and 290 K is given in Figure . It is apparent that for pressure step 1.5–2 bar, adsorption at 290 K was ∼2–3× faster than at 195 K. At 10–11 bar, the profiles have similar kinetics although the amounts adsorbed are quite different.

elements.content: The activation energies (E a,n) for methane and carbon dioxide diffusion into NPC-4 were calculated for various amounts adsorbed (n) using the SE model, and the results are shown in Figure . The E a,n values for CO2 adsorption on NPC-4 were in the range 5.1–6.3 kJ mol–1 for uptakes in the range 2–13.5 mmol g–1 with no significant variation with amount adsorbed (see Table S5, ). An activation energy of 7.6 kJ mol–1 has been reported for CO2 diffusion into MOF-5. The activation energies values for CH4 adsorption were in the range 2.7–5.6 kJ mol–1 for amounts adsorbed in the range 2–9 mmol g–1 (see Table S6, ), which is similar to 3.0 kJ mol–1 observed from quasi elastic neutron scattering (QENS) for diffusion NaY zeolite. The results on the temperature dependence of CBRD parameters k b and k d for both CO2 and CH4 adsorption are consistent with low activation energies (E a,n). The values for the surface barrier (k b) and diffusion along pores (k d) for CH4 were < 3 kJ mol−1 and < 9 kJ mol−1, respectively. Diffusion through the porous structure is not only controlled by the size of the windows. An increase in diffusion is observed when the characteristic length scales of molecules and cavities are similar. CO2 (3.339 × 3.189 × 5.361 Å) and CH4 (3.829 × 3.942 × 4.101 Å) are much smaller than the size of the cages (16 Å) in NPC-4, and therefore, this is not an issue in NPC-4. The E a,n values for both CO2 and CH4 are much lower than the corresponding isosteric enthalpy of adsorption. This indicates that molecular sieving through a barrier due to window constrictions in the porosity interconnecting the cages is not the rate-determining step. Activation energies and enthalpies of adsorption are usually different.
elements.clean_text:
Adsorption Activation Energies

The activation energies (E a,n) for methane and carbon dioxide diffusion into NPC-4 were calculated for various amounts adsorbed (n) using the SE model, and the results are shown in Figure . The E a,n values for CO2 adsorption on NPC-4 were in the range 5.1-6.3 kJ mol-1 for uptakes in the range 2-13.5 mmol g-1 with no significant variation with amount adsorbed (see Table S5, ). An activation energy of 7.6 kJ mol-1 has been reported for CO2 diffusion into MOF-5. The activation energies values for CH4 adsorption were in the range 2.7-5.6 kJ mol-1 for amounts adsorbed in the range 2-9 mmol g-1 (see Table S6, ), which is similar to 3.0 kJ mol-1 observed from quasi elastic neutron scattering (QENS) for diffusion NaY zeolite. The results on the temperature dependence of CBRD parameters k b and k d for both CO2 and CH4 adsorption are consistent with low activation energies (E a,n). The values for the surface barrier (k b) and diffusion along pores (k d) for CH4 were < 3 kJ mol-1 and < 9 kJ mol-1, respectively. Diffusion through the porous structure is not only controlled by the size of the windows. An increase in diffusion is observed when the characteristic length scales of molecules and cavities are similar. CO2 (3.339 × 3.189 × 5.361 Å) and CH4 (3.829 × 3.942 × 4.101 Å) are much smaller than the size of the cages (16 Å) in NPC-4, and therefore, this is not an issue in NPC-4. The E a,n values for both CO2 and CH4 are much lower than the corresponding isosteric enthalpy of adsorption. This indicates that molecular sieving through a barrier due to window constrictions in the porosity interconnecting the cages is not the rate-determining step. Activation energies and enthalpies of adsorption are usually different.

elements.content: Studies of quantitative structure–property relationships for MOFs suggest that for methane storage at 35 bar, they should have densities > 0.43 g cm–3 and void fractions > 0.52; and for storage at 100 bar, MOFs should have densities > 0.33 g cm–3 and void fractions > 0.62. The optimal BET surface areas for storage were 2500–3000 m2 g–1. MOFs with alkyl groups on the linkers are among the best storage materials. In comparison, NPC-4 has a pore space ratio of 0.61, crystallographic density of 0.832 g cm–3, and BET surface area of 1816 m2 g–1.
elements.clean_text:
Pore Structure and Adsorption Characteristics

Studies of quantitative structure-property relationships for MOFs suggest that for methane storage at 35 bar, they should have densities > 0.43 g cm-3 and void fractions > 0.52; and for storage at 100 bar, MOFs should have densities > 0.33 g cm-3 and void fractions > 0.62. The optimal BET surface areas for storage were 2500-3000 m2 g-1. MOFs with alkyl groups on the linkers are among the best storage materials. In comparison, NPC-4 has a pore space ratio of 0.61, crystallographic density of 0.832 g cm-3, and BET surface area of 1816 m2 g-1.

elements.content: The CO2 and CH4 kinetic parameters for adsorption on NPC-4 are compared with similar data for a carbon molecular sieve, which was suitable for air separation, in Figure . Only the relative kinetics for CO2 and CH4 should be compared because CMSA has kinetic selectivity incorporated by carbon deposition on a heterogeneous microporous carbon substrate. The microcrystallites are surrounded by kinetically selective porosity in the pellets and not uniformly distributed in the material. Particle size reduction results in loss of kinetic selectivity. The CO2 and CH4 data for CMSA only overlap at 343 K , and CO2 is >200× faster than CH4 under these conditions and hence, it has exceptional kinetic selectivity for separation of CH4 and CO2 by molecular sieving. The kinetic molecular sieving selectivity is attributed to the smaller cross section of CO2 (∼3.3 Å) compared with CH4 (4 Å). In contrast, the CO2 and CH4 adsorption kinetic data for NPC-4 show that CO2 is 0.24–0.38× the rate for CH4 adsorption at the same surface coverage. These differences in relative kinetics are related to the influence of pore structure on the rate-determining step in the diffusion mechanism as shown by the kinetic and thermodynamic parameters in Table . The isosteric enthalpy of adsorption at zero surface coverage (Q st,n=0) on CMSA were 28.4 and 23.8 kJ mol–1 for CO2 and CH4, respectively, while the corresponding activation energies at zero surface coverage (E a,n=0) from the LDF model were 41 and 54 kJ mol–1 for CO2 and CH4, respectively. E a,n=0 was greater than Q st,n=0 for both CH4 and CO2 adsorption on CMSA.

elements.content:
Comparison of Isosteric Enthalpies of Adsorption, Activation Energies, Enthalpies of Activation (kJ mol<sup>–1</sup>), and Pre-Exponential Factors (ln­(s<sup>–1</sup>)) for NPC-4 and a Carbon Molecular Sieve (CMSA)<xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t3fn1"></xref> CO2 CH4 NPC-4 Q st,n=0 23.17 ± 0.10 15.18 ± 0.09 Q st,n 24.5–25.5 15.0–16.0 E a,n 5.1–6.3 2.7–5.5 Δ H ‡ n 3.1–4.3 0.8–3.6 ln (A) –1.4 to −2.5 –1.1–2.8 CMSA Q st n=0 28.4 ± 0.7 23.8 ± 1.1 Q st,n 21.9–28.3 19.9–24.1 E a,n=0 41.1 ± 2.1 53.6 ± 2.2 E a,n 38.4–34.4 53.6–55.6 ln (A) 7.1–9.1 8.1–9.1

Q st,n=0 was determined using a virial equation to extrapolate the isotherm data to obtain ln­(K H) at zero surface coverage, where K H is the Henry’s law constant. Q st,n was calculated by linear interpolation of absolute isotherm data and graphs ln­(p) versus 1/T. E a,n=0 was calculated from the linear graphs of ln­(k) versus amount adsorbed. E a,n values were calculated by linear interpolation of the ln­(k) versus amount adsorbed. The Q st,n data for high pressure CO2 adsorption on NPC-4 were calculated from absolute adsorption isotherms at 198 K up to 1 bar, and 273 and 303 K up to 20 bar, and are for uptakes in the range 0.5–15.5 mmol g–1. The Q st,n data for CH4 adsorption on NPC-4 were calculated from absolute adsorption isotherms at 195, 270, 280, and 290 K up to 20 bar. The data for CMSA are taken from the literature. , The Q st,n data for CO2 adsorption on CMSA were calculated from absolute adsorption isotherms at 313–343 K and are for uptakes in the range 0.1–1.5 mmol g–1. The Q st,n data for CH4 adsorption on CMSA were calculated from absolute adsorption isotherms at 368–358 K and pressures up to 1 bar. The uptakes were in the range 0.1–0.4 mmol g–1.

CH4 adsorption was significantly faster than CO2 adsorption on NPC-4. Diffusion through the pore cages in NPC-4 is related to the strength of the adsorbate–adsorbent interaction at low surface coverage. Q st,n=0 is a fundamental measure of the adsorbate–adsorbent interaction. At high surface coverage, adsorbate–adsorbate interactions may also influence adsorption dynamics. Virial analysis of CO2 and CH4 adsorption isotherms for NPC-4 at low pressure shows that A 1 parameters are small and hence the adsorbate–adsorbate interactions are very weak at low uptakes (see Figures S21 and S23, ). Both CH4 and CO2 have very low activation energies (E a,n) and enthalpies of activation (Δ H ‡ n) for adsorption, which are much lower than the corresponding Q st,n. The activation energy, enthalpy of activation, and enthalpy of adsorption do not change significantly with change in amount adsorbed. The enthalpies of activation (ΔH ‡ n) were ∼1.9–2 kJ mol–1 (RT) lower than the corresponding activation energy. Therefore, the low E a,n and Δ H ‡ n values for both CH4 and CO2 adsorption indicate that kinetic molecular sieving through the windows (dimensions 5.3 × 6.3 Å) in the pore structure does not have a significant influence on adsorption dynamics. Diffusion of gases through pores, comprising cages linked by windows, is the rate determining process at low uptake since the activation energies are low. The surface resistance barrier is the rate determining process at high uptakes. The higher Q st for CO2 produces a slower surface hopping process than CH4, and this is the rate determining diffusion mechanism. The window dimensions are too large to influence diffusion of CH4 and CO2 through the porous structure by molecular sieving effects. Probe molecule studies have shown that the selective porosity in CMSA behaves as though it has spherical characteristics and can adsorb molecules with a cross section diameter of ∼<4 Å with rates that vary by greater than 3 orders of magnitude. Therefore, the pore window dimensions are very critical for kinetic molecular sieving. The adsorption kinetics for CO2 and CH4 on NPC-4 are very close to an LDF model at high uptakes similar to that observed for diffusion of O2, N2, CO2, etc. into carbon molecular sieve CMSA.

The enthalpies of activation (ΔH ‡ n) were ~1.9-2 kJ mol-1 (RT) lower than the corresponding activation energy. Therefore, the low E a,n and Δ H  ‡ n values for both CH4 and CO2 adsorption indicate that kinetic molecular sieving through the windows (dimensions 5.3 × 6.3 Å) in the pore structure does not have a significant influence on adsorption dynamics. Diffusion of gases through pores, comprising cages linked by windows, is the rate determining process at low uptake since the activation energies are low. The surface resistance barrier is the rate determining process at high uptakes. The higher Q st for CO2 produces a slower surface hopping process than CH4, and this is the rate determining diffusion mechanism. The window dimensions are too large to influence diffusion of CH4 and CO2 through the porous structure by molecular sieving effects. Probe molecule studies have shown that the selective porosity in CMSA behaves as though it has spherical characteristics and can adsorb molecules with a cross section diameter of ~<4 Å with rates that vary by greater than 3 orders of magnitude. Therefore, the pore window dimensions are very critical for kinetic molecular sieving. The adsorption kinetics for CO2 and CH4 on NPC-4 are very close to an LDF model at high uptakes similar to that observed for diffusion of O2, N2, CO2, etc. into carbon molecular sieve CMSA.

elements.content: Models based on diffusion through windows and pore cavities have been used previously to describe diffusion of ethanol and methanol into the M and E template structural phases of Ni2(4,4′-bipyridine)3·(NO3)4 and ethanol into ZIF-8. In the Ni2(4,4′-bipyridine)3·(NO3)4 system, examples of activation energies higher than Q st,n were observed for diffusion through windows and low barriers less than Q st,n for diffusion along pore cavities. In these particular situations, where diffusion through windows occurred, the framework had structural flexibility. The Darken equation for isotherms, which follow the Langmuir equation, predicts that diffusivity should be related to 1/(1 – φ), where φ is surface coverage and should increase with increasing surface coverage. This has been observed for diffusion of ethanol into MOF Ni2(4,4′-bipyridine)3·(NO3)4. Diffusion of methanol into ZIF-8 is dominated by intercage hopping and strong methanol–methanol interactions.

elements.content: The adsorption isotherms for both CH4 and CO2 adsorption on NPC-4 are type 1 and fit the Langmuir equation. However, the diffusion characteristics of CO2 and CH4 into NPC-4 are different. Initially, the adsorption of both CH4 and CO2 is fast, and rate of adsorption decreases to a shallow minimum where there is relatively constant diffusivity. The Q st,n and E a,n values for both CO2 and CH4 show that Q st,n > E a,n, and these parameters do not vary markedly with amount adsorbed. The CO2 plateau is reached at ∼15% of maximum loading (∼3 mmol g–1 or ∼1 CO2 per crystallographic formula unit) (see Figure a). In the case of CH4, the minimum in diffusivity is not reached until higher uptake, but this depends on temperature (see Figure b). The low E a,n values for both CO2 and CH4 indicate that diffusion through windows is not the rate determining process.

elements.content: These results of CO2 subcritical adsorption kinetics at 198 K show that they do not vary greatly with uptake for a major part (3–15 mmol g–1, 15–75% of uptake at 1 bar) of the isotherm and follow the LDF mechanism. However, the CBRD model is followed for uptakes in the range 15–19 mmol g–1 (Figure S33d, ) before changing back to LDF close to pore filling (Figure S33e,f, ). The CBRD k d parameter is low (6.511 × 10–13 m2 s–1), while k b was 1.065 × 10–7 m s–1 for pressure increment 300–400 mbar. Therefore, diffusion along pores in NPC-4 influences the kinetics in this uptake range. In diffusion through nanocages, an increased collision frequency with other molecules confined in nanocages at higher uptakes will lead to a shorter mean hopping distance and lower diffusivity. As loading increases, collision frequency and diffusion resistance increase due to molecular collisions in the limited space available when confined in nanocages, while at the same time, the chemical potential gradient increases favoring faster diffusion. Slow diffusion along pores due to confinement in nanocages is an explanation of CBRD kinetics in the 15–19 mmol g–1 uptake range.
