elements.content: Transport diffusivities obtained from macroscopic measurements are often controlled by extra-crystalline transport resistances. Self-diffusivity, which involves random particle movement, may exceed the transport diffusivity if there are strong intermolecular interactions. This is not the case for CO2 and CH4 adsorption on NPC-4. The self-diffusion coefficients determined for methane on MIL-53­(Cr) using QENS and nuclear magnetic resonance gave values 1.7 × 10–7–4.2 × 10–7 m2 s–1. These values are larger than the transport diffusivities observed in this study, and an explanation is that a surface barrier mainly controls adsorption kinetics in NPC-4 at high uptakes.

These values are larger than the transport diffusivities observed in this study, and an explanation is that a surface barrier mainly controls adsorption kinetics in NPC-4 at high uptakes.

elements.content: A novel highly stable nanoporous metal–organic framework NPC-4 was synthesized using a methyl-substituted carboxylate (TMBDI) ligand and paddle-wheel (Cu2(COO)4) SBUs, which have excellent thermal stability. The methyl-substituted carboxylate ligands in NPC-4 form a porous structure comprising nanocages (16 Å) connected by windows (5.2 Å × 6.3 Å). This represents a good compromise between the requirements of high loading capacities and favorable transport properties for methane and carbon dioxide storage. NPC-4 exhibits high methane and carbon dioxide storage capacity on a volume basis under ambient conditions. The isosteric enthalpies of adsorption for methane and carbon dioxide were 15–16 and 23–25 kJ mol–1, respectively. These values are relatively low and do not vary significantly with the amount adsorbed indicating that the unsaturated metal centers in NPC-4 do not have a significant impact on methane and carbon dioxide adsorption thermodynamics. Both the CO2 and CH4 adsorbate densities are relatively high indicating enhancement by the nanocage structure. The isobars for both CH4 and CO2 adsorption on NPC-4 show that the variation of adsorption capacity with temperature can be described by a linear model. At low uptake, the stretched exponential adsorption kinetics for both CO2 and CH4 are very fast and decrease to a shallow minimum where the kinetics do not vary greatly for a large uptake range. The adsorption and desorption kinetics for both CH4 and CO2 are reasonably fast even at 195 K. The activation energies for the adsorption kinetics for CO2 and CH4 obtained from the SE model were <6 kJ mol–1. The surface and pore diffusion barriers derived from the CBRD model were both <9 kJ mol–1. The activation energies do not vary greatly with amount adsorbed and are significantly lower than the corresponding isosteric enthalpy of adsorption. The CBRD kinetic parameters for diffusion along the pores have low activation energies and do not vary markedly with amount adsorbed. This indicates that kinetic molecular sieving effects for diffusion of both CH4 and CO2 through the narrow windows (5.2 × 6.3 Å) are not significant. Diffusion through pores consisting of interconnected nanocages (16 Å diameter) is the rate determining process in the diffusion mechanism at low uptake. At high uptake, the surface barrier controls the adsorption kinetics. The faster adsorption for CH4, which has a larger cross section than CO2, is due to the lower isosteric enthalpy of adsorption of CH4 on NPC-4. Kinetic molecular sieving effects for CH4 and CO2 only occur for windows with smaller dimensions than those in NPC-4. These advantages of high storage capacity, favorable adsorption and desorption kinetics, and excellent thermal stability make NPC-4 a good compromise for practical storage applications, where the compressed gas stored between the particles in the bed and in larger macropores are also considerations. It is evident that when considering storage of gases on porous materials, both adsorption capacity and dynamics need to be considered.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A novel highly stable nanoporous metal-organic framework NPC-4 was synthesized using a methyl-substituted carboxylate (TMBDI) ligand and paddle-wheel (Cu2(COO)4) SBUs, which have excellent thermal stability. The methyl-substituted carboxylate ligands in NPC-4 form a porous structure comprising nanocages (16 Å) connected by windows (5.2 Å × 6.3 Å). This represents a good compromise between the requirements of high loading capacities and favorable transport properties for methane and carbon dioxide storage. NPC-4 exhibits high methane and carbon dioxide storage capacity on a volume basis under ambient conditions. The isosteric enthalpies of adsorption for methane and carbon dioxide were 15-16 and 23-25 kJ mol-1, respectively. These values are relatively low and do not vary significantly with the amount adsorbed indicating that the unsaturated metal centers in NPC-4 do not have a significant impact on methane and carbon dioxide adsorption thermodynamics. Both the CO2 and CH4 adsorbate densities are relatively high indicating enhancement by the nanocage structure. The isobars for both CH4 and CO2 adsorption on NPC-4 show that the variation of adsorption capacity with temperature can be described by a linear model. At low uptake, the stretched exponential adsorption kinetics for both CO2 and CH4 are very fast and decrease to a shallow minimum where the kinetics do not vary greatly for a large uptake range. The adsorption and desorption kinetics for both CH4 and CO2 are reasonably fast even at 195 K. The activation energies for the adsorption kinetics for CO2 and CH4 obtained from the SE model were <6 kJ mol-1. The surface and pore diffusion barriers derived from the CBRD model were both <9 kJ mol-1. The activation energies do not vary greatly with amount adsorbed and are significantly lower than the corresponding isosteric enthalpy of adsorption. The CBRD kinetic parameters for diffusion along the pores have low activation energies and do not vary markedly with amount adsorbed. This indicates that kinetic molecular sieving effects for diffusion of both CH4 and CO2 through the narrow windows (5.2 × 6.3 Å) are not significant. Diffusion through pores consisting of interconnected nanocages (16 Å diameter) is the rate determining process in the diffusion mechanism at low uptake. At high uptake, the surface barrier controls the adsorption kinetics. The faster adsorption for CH4, which has a larger cross section than CO2, is due to the lower isosteric enthalpy of adsorption of CH4 on NPC-4. Kinetic molecular sieving effects for CH4 and CO2 only occur for windows with smaller dimensions than those in NPC-4. These advantages of high storage capacity, favorable adsorption and desorption kinetics, and excellent thermal stability make NPC-4 a good compromise for practical storage applications, where the compressed gas stored between the particles in the bed and in larger macropores are also considerations. It is evident that when considering storage of gases on porous materials, both adsorption capacity and dynamics need to be considered.

elements.content: Details of ligand synthesis, synthesis of NPC-4, and hydro-thermal stability are given in sections S1–S3, respectively. Single-crystal X-ray crystallography structure refinement information and structural representations of NPC-4 are given in sections S4 and S5. The infrared spectrum of NPC-4 is shown in section S6. The gas adsorption data are included in sections S7–S11 and includes gas adsorption isotherms, calculation of BET and Langmuir surface areas, isosteric adsorption enthalpy calculation procedures, simulation of CH4 adsorption on NPC-4 for pressure range 20–35 bar, and kinetic data. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org. CCDC 915001 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

cln_elements.content: NPC-4 was synthesized by solvothermal reaction of TMBDI and Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O in the solution of DMA and H2O with the addition of HNO3. TMBDI (0.092 g, 0.2 mmol) and Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O (0.096 g, 0.4 mmol) were dissolved in DMA/H2O (3:1, 24 mL), and then 2 mL of concentrated HNO3 was added. The resulting mixture was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container and was heated to 373 K for 72 h. After cooling to room temperature at a rate of 0.05 K min–1, the pure phase of blue crystals was obtained and separated by filtration. A typical scanning electron micrograph of the crystals is shown in (see Figure S2). Anal. Calcd (Found, %): C, 46.8 (47.2), H, 5.46 (5.65), N, 3.53 (3.62). IR (KBr): ν­(cm–1) = 1629 (vs), 1510 (w), 1433 (m), 1384 (vs), 1258 (m), 1183 (w), 1090 (w), 1047 (w), 919 (w), 874 (w), 773 (m), 731 (m) (see Figure S12, ). The compound was formulated as [Cu2(TMBDI)­(H2O)2]­(DMA)2.5(H2O)4 on the basis of single-crystal X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and elemental analysis.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Materials Synthesis and Characterization

NPC-4 was synthesized by solvothermal reaction of TMBDI and Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O in the solution of DMA and H2O with the addition of HNO3. TMBDI (0.092 g, 0.2 mmol) and Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.096 g, 0.4 mmol) were dissolved in DMA/H2O (3:1, 24 mL), and then 2 mL of concentrated HNO3 was added. The resulting mixture was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container and was heated to 373 K for 72 h. After cooling to room temperature at a rate of 0.05 K min-1, the pure phase of blue crystals was obtained and separated by filtration. A typical scanning electron micrograph of the crystals is shown in  (see Figure S2). Anal. Calcd (Found, %): C, 46.8 (47.2), H, 5.46 (5.65), N, 3.53 (3.62). IR (KBr): ν(cm-1) = 1629 (vs), 1510 (w), 1433 (m), 1384 (vs), 1258 (m), 1183 (w), 1090 (w), 1047 (w), 919 (w), 874 (w), 773 (m), 731 (m) (see Figure S12, ). The compound was formulated as [Cu2(TMBDI)(H2O)2](DMA)2.5(H2O)4 on the basis of single-crystal X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and elemental analysis.

cln_elements.content:
Crystal data for NPC-4: C13H11O5Cu, M = 310.77 g mol–1, tetragonal, space group I4/mmm, a = b = 18.945(4) Å, c = 27.561(10) Å, T = 293 K, V = 9892(5) Å3, Z = 16, total reflections = 13150, independent reflections = 2473, GOF = 1.07, R 1[F 0 > 2σ­(F 0)] = 0.0667, wR 2 = 0.1418 for all data (see Table S1, ).

Porous Structure Characterization

The nitrogen absolute isotherm of NPC-4 at 77 K exhibits typical reversible type-I shape in the IUPAC Classification Scheme with an uptake of 61.1 wt % at 1 bar (Figure a). The total pore volume (calculated using ρ­(N2) = 0.8081 g cm–3) and total void space ratio calculated for NPC-4 were 0.756 cm3 g–1 and 62.9%, respectively, which is consistent with the value (0.781 cm3 g–1) obtained from crystallographic data using PLATON, indicating that the guest molecules are completely removed during the activation process without framework collapse. This is supported by the TGA plot (Figure ) and PXRD profiles (Figure ). The BET graph has a slight curvature, and the surface area calculated from the N2 isotherm in low-pressure range (0.01 < p/p 0 < 0.085) was 1816 m2 g–1 (see , Figure S15), which is comparable to NOTT-107 and PCN-14, and the Langmuir surface area was 2130 m2 g–1 (see , Figure S16). The high value of the BET c parameter (1253) is indicative of micropore filling. H2 adsorption isotherm on NPC-4 at 77 K is given in Figure b. At 77 K and 1 bar, the uptake of H2 in NPC-4 was 2.3 wt % , and the surface excess of H2 for NPC-4 was 4.5 wt % at 77 K and 20 bar. The latter H2 uptake at 20 bar is similar to other materials with similar surface areas.

A = absolute; E = surface excess.

Methane uptake capacities at 290 K and 35 bar in NPC-4 were predicted using the Langmuir equation using the absolute CH4 isotherm data for 10–20 bar.

The gravimetric methane uptake capacity in UTSA-20 is calculated by multiplying the density of adsorbed CH4 with the pore volume of UTSA-20.
